text: The beast lets out a harsh snarl, the rocky armor along its limbs gleaming dark green under the light. Each heavy breath rattles, and every step makes the ground tremble.
I study its movements, trying to find a pattern. It moves fast despite its weight, stones scattering with every landing. My heartbeat grows louder in my ears.
I think I see an opening and shout, “Alicia! Its left leg—” But before I can finish, the creature suddenly lunges in the opposite direction.
I can’t dodge in time. The impact sends me crashing to the ground. My vision spins as leaves and dust whirl in front of me.
In that instant, a streak of silver cuts through the air. Alicia charges forward, nearly brushing past the monster as her blade sweeps across its neck.
The beast releases a piercing shriek. Its body stiffens, then dissolves into ash. The smell of scorched earth spreads through the clearing.

I lie on my back, chest heaving. Alicia rushes over and drops to one knee, checking me over with a frown. “What were you thinking? Creatures like this don’t move in ways you can predict unless you’ve fought for years.”
I struggle to answer. She sighs, her tone softening. “I’m not blaming you. Just… don’t try to figure everything out on your own. Leave it to me.”
She tears a strip of cloth and wipes the blood from my arm, her movements so gentle they’re almost silent. Her expression shifts from tension to something softer. “Does it hurt?”
“I can handle it.” I force a grin. “Next time I’ll be sure.”
She presses her lips together, sounding faintly exasperated. “You just like to show off.”
The wind drifts through the trees. She glances at the scorched ground, her expression gradually returning to calm.
“It wasn’t born naturally. It’s a ‘Lingering Dream’—a trace left behind by those who died.”
“Yes. In places where wars were fought and people died, their final emotions sink into the earth. Over time, they become things like this.”
After a pause, she adds quietly, “Don’t scare me like that again. Alright?”
I blink, then grin faintly. “Is that concern?” She shoots me a look but doesn’t deny it. Instead, she reaches out and pulls me to my feet.
“Come on. The market’s just ahead. When we’re back in town, I’ll find something to treat that.”
